Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering education research project focuses on the development of a program called AccessEngineering, modeled after existing programs Accesscomputing and AccessSTEM. This is a workforce development activity that utilizes communities of practice, webinars, mini-grants, Capacity Building Institutes and an on-line clearinghouse to broaden the participation of persons with disabilities in engineering education and careers. Recognizing that there is a need to both increase and diversify the engineering workforce, the overarching goal of this project is to increase the participation of persons with disabilities in engineering education and workforce. This is achieved through a nationwide engagement of faculty and students in efforts to make engineering content accessible to all students, including students with disabilities.

The broader significance and importance of this project is that by educating faculty about the importance of accessible design, providing seed funding to enable incorporation of universal design principles in educational content, and creating a community of practice linked through Capacity Building Institutes, this project will address factors that directly inhibit the participation of students with disabilities in engineering education and the workforce. Engineering faculty will have access to a content rich website of research and practice in broadening participation that was developed as part of prior efforts. This project will enhance the content of this widely available website to include case studies from faculty using Universal Design in their course content development, proceedings from the Capacity Building Institutes, a collection of biographies of students with disabilities engaged in engineering and others artefacts from this project.

This project overlaps with NSF's strategic goal of broadening participation in engineering by increasing access to engineering education for groups that are currently underrepresented in the engineering workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
AccessEngineering was funded (grant #EEC-1444961) by the National Science Foundation (NSF) under the Broadening Participation in Engineering (BPE) Strategy Track (BPE-ST). Overarching goals of AccessEngineering were to (1) increase the successful participation of people with disabilities in education and careers in engineering and (2) improve engineering fields with their perspectives and expertise. AccessEngineering?s objectives were to help engineering faculty at a broad range of institutions to

  • Better serve a diverse student body, including students with a broad range of disabilities, in engineering courses and programs, and
  • Integrate relevant disability-related and universal design content into engineering courses. 

AccessEngineering engaged engineering faculty nationwide in research-based practices, many developed by NSF-funded projects, that support the project objectives. Activities included the following:

  • Capacity-Building Institutes (CBIs). Three CBIs that engaged a total of 124 people were conducted. CBI agendas included presentations about including students with disabilities in engineering courses using research-based UD and accommodation strategies, the inclusion of disability-related and UD content within courses, a panel of students and engineering professionals with disabilities who shared their experiences, and work groups that explored issues and identified interventions to support the project objectives and systemic change. CBI proceedings were shared via the website, through communities of practice (CoPs), at conferences, and within published articles.
  • Communities of Practice (CoP). 149 AccessEngineering staff and faculty leaders engaged in an online CoP that includes key stakeholder groups that impact the success of students with disabilities in engineering programs (e.g., faculty, disability service units, online learning programs, veterans associations, career services, teaching and learning centers, diversity programs, professional organizations) to share ideas and assist in the creation and dissemination of resources to encourage others to help a broader range of students pursue engineering fields and support them in their studies.
  • Professional Development. AccessEngineering engaged 411 participants in 12 webinars. Three of the events were integrated into courses that are being offered for multiple years after the end of the grant and will add an estimated 500-1,000 views a year.
  • Minigrants. Faculty leaders and CBI and CoP participants in AccessEngineering were eligible to apply for minigrants to support activities that contributed to the project goals and objectives. Minigrants were for up to $3000 towards the direct costs (e.g., hourly salaries of students with disabilities to participate on panels or assist with the project, materials for student design project teams, refreshments for meetings, purchase and distribution of materials) of a project. In total 14 minigrants were funded, reaching 400 individuals.
  • Online Clearinghouse and Dissemination. Project activities and products were informed by the body of knowledge that surrounds important research and practice questions regarding broadening participation in engineering and added to that knowledge base. In collaboration with faculty leadership and CBI and CoP participants, AccessEngineering added to the product collections developed by earlier projects and linked to other relevant resources to create a comprehensive collection of products that supported project goals and objectives. The AccessEngineering website is located at www.uw.edu/doit/programs/accessengineering/overview. All project products were presented in accessible formats and are freely available online. Highlighted products include
    • the AccessEngineering Knowledge Base, containing 355 articles;
    • three peer-reviewed articles and 13 other articles;
    • five project brochures (Equal Access: Universal Design of Engineering Labs, Checklist for Making Engineering Labs Accessible to Students with Disabilities, Equal Access: Universal Design of Engineering Departments, Making a Makerspace? Guidelines for Accessibility and Universal Design, and AccessEngineering: Promoting the Success of People with Disabilities in Engineering and Incorporating Universal Design in Engineering Curricula);
    • three proceedings from Capacity Building Institutes; and
    • three videos (Disability and Accessibility in Engineering: What Can Educators Do?, Broadening Participation in Engineering to Include People with Disabilities, and Engaging Individuals with Disabilities in an Engineering Research Center).

 More than 10,901 copies of project materials were disseminated. To ensure long-term impact, project products were disseminated widely online, through collaborators, and at engineering conferences. Resources developed and lessons learned by AccessEngineering were shared at conferences and through DO-IT?s extensive network of online stakeholder forums. The DO-IT Center will continue to share project outcomes and products through its Knowledge Base, publications, and videos and at conferences attended as part of future projects; the CoP will also continue to be supported.

AccessEngineering advanced NSF?s strategic goal to cultivate a world-class, broadly inclusive science and engineering workforce. It will have broad impact because it

  • Engaged diverse teams of engineering students and faculty, including early- and mid-career faculty; created synergy within and between campuses; and promoted systemic change;
  • Built on existing networks for engagement of and dissemination to multiple stakeholder groups;
  • Employed and developed practices that were scalable, had wide applicability, and were sustainable; and
  • Compiled, created, and broadly disseminated products with information about transformational research and practice and ensured that all products were accessible to individuals with disabilities.
